pageData.text: In this activity, students sample locations of their choosing to test for the presence of <button class='glossary-text'>microbes</button> and grow the collected bacteria and fungi in <button class='glossary-text'>culture</button>. Students will make predictions about the amount of microbes present in their surroundings, <button class='glossary-text'>inoculate</button> their samples onto growth media, incubate the cultures, and observe the growth of the microbes present.

pageData.text: Every plant and animal are hosts to a diversity of symbiotic and viruses. It is estimated that the human microbiome consists of 10-100 trillion symbiotic microbial cells, outnumbering human cells 10 to 1. Microbial symbionts can be transmitted from parent to offspring by a variety of methods, including before birth, and direct contact during and after birth. Microbial symbionts can also be acquired through the environment. We are finding that microbes may play an even bigger role in our lives than we thought. Research suggests that microbes are involved in animal – and human – mate selection. It is hypothesized that the ability to detect chemical cues emitted by the microbiome may subconsciously provide insight into a potential mate’s genetic make-up and their susceptibility to . Although the exact mechanism is not understood, couples who have different pathogen-recognizing HLA genes suffer fewer miscarriages and their children have a heterozygote advantage, potentially with an enhanced ability to fight infections. This might have helped ancient humans survive epidemics1.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Microbes</button> are organisms and infectious particles too small to be seen with the unaided eye. The bacteria and archaea are prokaryotic microbes, single-celled organisms that lack a nucleus. Other microbes, such as protozoa, algae, and fungi, are eukaryotic, and they have a nucleus. Still others are non-cellular, infectious particles—much simpler than any living cell, but able to infect cellular life forms in order to reproduce. These include viruses, which consist of nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) enclosed in a protein coat, sometimes surrounded by a membranous envelope. Prions are infectious protein particles, and viroids are composed only of RNA.

Microbes are incredibly diverse. The bacteria alone include untold thousands of species. Microbes use a wide variety of different life-styles to survive in their environments. Most are , meaning they do not depend on a host organism for survival. These microbes may exist as producers (or autotrophs) in the food chain, generating their own food, for example, by photosynthesis. Others are consumers (or heterotrophs), such as , which decompose dead organic material to obtain nutrients for their own growth. Some heterotrophic microbes even prey on smaller microbes. A much smaller proportion of heterotrophic microbes are , which obtain nutrients from larger host organisms. When microbes cause disease, they are said to be . Some microbes are pathogens; i.e., they are generally free-living, but can cause disease if given the opportunity.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A diagram of microbe classification. Microbes can be acellular or cellular. Acellular microbes can either contain nucleic acids (DNA/RNA) or not. Acellular microbes with nucleic acids include bacteriophage that infect bacteria, viruses that infect eukaryotic cells, and viroids that infect plants. Acellular microbes without nucleic acids include prions that infect animals such as humans, cows and sheep. Cellular microbes may or may not have a nucleus. Cellular microbes without a nucleus are prokaryotes. Pro meaning before and kary meaning nucleus. They are unicellular and lack membrane-bound organelles. Examples of prokaryotes include archaea and bacteria. Cellular microbes with a nucleus are eukaryotes. Eu meaning true and kary meaning nucleus. They have membrane-bound organelles. Examples of eukaryotes include algae, protozoa, fungi, plants and animals.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Microbes</button> are ubiquitous—they are found practically everywhere. Microbes inhabit every region of Earth’s <button class='glossary-text'>biosphere</button>—the region of the planet that supports life—from the icy reaches of Antarctica to the superheated waters of the hot springs in Yellowstone National Park; from high in the atmosphere to deep beneath the earth’s surface. Highly resistant dormant forms of bacteria called <button class='glossary-text'>endospores</button> have been found surviving in a 250-million-year-old salt crystal. The human body carries immense numbers of microbial cells as well. In fact, there are 10 times more bacterial cells than human cells in the human body, and microbes can be found from the surface of the skin to deep within the intestines.

Different communities of microbes inhabit the various niches of the biosphere. A microbial community inhabiting dental plaque will be extremely different in species composition from a community growing inside a municipal water pipe. Samples obtained from a particular envi-ronmental source are likely to contain a mixture of several different species. Because the human body is inhabited by communities of microbes, it is very important that <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic technique</button> is used when obtaining an environmental sample. Aseptic technique is a set of procedures for handling microbes that is aimed at avoiding contamination and includes the preparation of <button class='glossary-text'>sterile</button> (microbe-free) media and <button class='glossary-text'>disinfection</button> of work areas to greatly reduce the number of microbes present. Unless aseptic technique is employed, accidental contamination of the sample with the individual’s microbes, or microbes present in airborne dust, may occur.

pageData.text: collected from the environment must be provided with all the resources they need to survive. Moisture, nutrients, and temperature are just a few factors that must be considered when cultivating various types of microbes. Determining the conditions needed to grow a particular microbe can be very challenging. Indeed, many microbes are currently considered to be because no one has yet discovered how to recreate the conditions necessary for their growth. One important component of culturing microbes is the (plural, media), the substrate within or on which the microbes will grow. Media may be liquid, or they may contain a solidifying agent, such as . Nutrient agar, which will be used in this exercise, is considered a general-purpose medium, because many (but not all) types of microbes can grow on it.

After adding microbes to—or <button class='glossary-text'>inoculating</button>—the medium, the resulting <button class='glossary-text'>culture</button> must then be placed in favorable growth conditions. Some microbes grow best at warmer temperatures, such as those found within the human body. Others prefer cooler temperatures, such as those found deep in the soil. In this investigation, cultures will be maintained at room temperature, which can vary widely, but is generally considered to be approximately 21°C (70°F).

You might expect that a microscope is needed to observe <button class='glossary-text'>microbes</button>. Surprisingly, this is often not the case. <button class='glossary-text'>Microbiologists</button>—biologists who specialize in the study of microbes—perform many <button class='glossary-text'>macroscopic</button> observations, meaning that they use the unaided eye. In this exercise, macroscopic observations will be made of growth resulting from the inoculation of samples onto nutrient <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button> maintained at room temperature. Some mounds of growth may appear and increase in size over time. These are termed <button class='glossary-text'>colonies</button> (Figure 2). A <button class='glossary-text'>colony</button> is an aggregation of cells descended from either a single cell or a small number of closely-adhering cells. Certain microbes, particularly among the bacteria and fungi, will form colonies when they are thinly spread on nutrient agar. Colonies may offer some clues as to the identity of the microbes in the sample. For example, certain species of fungi will produce fuzzy-looking colonies, whereas bacteria frequently generate colonies that are relatively smooth in appearance. If a particularly rich sample of microbes that grow well under the conditions of this investigation is obtained, the growth may be so abundant that it is not possible to distinguish individual colonies.

Caution: To swirl the media, using an oven mitt or pot holder, tighten the cap, and turn the bottle back and forth. If the media has not completely melted, loosen the cap, and microwave it for another 5 seconds. Repeat this process until the media is completely melted, continuously keeping an eye on the media to avoid any explosions.

Place a paper towel in the microwave. Place the bottle on the paper towel and warm it up in 5-second intervals. This step is very important to ensure the media does not explode in the microwave. pageData.text: Select three different sample sites.

Locations likely to yield large quantities of <button class='glossary-text'>microbes</button> include bathroom faucets, doorknobs, drinking fountains, bottoms of backpacks or purses, coins and paper currency, plant leaves, phones, stairway handrails, and computer mice and keyboards. You may wish to consider liquid sources, such as water from a stream, pond, or fish tank. Airborne microbes may also be sampled.
Caution: To reduce the risk of cultivating human avoid sampling sites such as toilet seats, soles of shoes, nose or throat, or body fluids.

Label the bottom of a nutrient agar plate with the source of your first sample using the grease pencil. Write along the edge of the plate bottom so as not to obscure your ability to observe the plate.
Obtain the first sample.

Consider how you will the plate with your sample.
  • Small solid objects, such as fingertips, coins, or paper currency, may be gently pressed against the agar in the Petri dish.
  • If a swab will be used to obtain the sample, apply the swab to the source by pressing firmly and rolling the swab repeatedly, so as to pick up as large a sample as possible. If the surface of the sample source is dry, the sterile swab may first be moistened by lifting the lid of the agar plate just enough to insert the swab and soaking up some of the condensed moisture on the inside of the lid. Once you have obtained the sample, inoculate your plate by streaking the swab gently but firmly across the surface of the solidified agar in a zigzag pattern. Discard used swabs after soaking them in bleach solution for at least 10 minutes.
  • Samples may be obtained from the air by simply taking the lid completely off the plate and setting it aside for 30 minutes. An interesting sample of scalp microbes—usually rich in fungi—can be obtained by removing the lid from a plate, then hanging the head over the plate and brushing the hair or massaging the scalp vigorously for several seconds before replacing the lid.
Repeat Steps 2 and 3 for the next two plates.
Watch this video on how to apply Parafilm<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> to a Petri dish.

pageData.text: Seal the gap between the two halves of each Petri dish using Parafilm<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>. Parafilm<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> is a stretchy, waxy material. To apply the Parafilm<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>, remove the paper backing, press one end of the Parafilm<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> against the Petri dish, stretch, and apply pressure (Figure 5). If one square of Parafilm<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> is insufficient to seal the gap, additional squares may be applied.
Invert the plates so that the side containing the agar is on top and the lid faces down.
Remove your gloves and discard them. Wash and dry your hands.
Caution: Do not open the plates! To do so is to risk contamination with microbes that could potentially cause disease.

data.title: Culture
data.content: A growth of microbes in a prepared nutrient medium

data.title: Disinfection
data.content: A process that eliminates many or all pathogenic microorganisms, except bacterial spores, on inanimate objects

data.title: Endospore
data.content: A resistant, asexual, dormant form of bacteria

data.title: Free-living
data.content: Describes organisms that do not depend on a host organism for survival

data.title: Inoculate
data.content: Introducing microbes into a culture media so that it can grow

data.title: Macroscopic
data.content: Can be seen with the unaided eye

data.title: Medium (media)
data.content: The substrate within or on which the microbes will grow; plural, media

data.title: Microbes
data.content: A broad term used to describe a diverse group of organism and infectious particles

data.title: Microbiologist
data.content: A biologist who specializes in the study of microbes

data.title: Non-culturable
data.content: Describes bacteria that are in a state of very low metabolic activity and do not divide on conventional media

data.title: Opportunistic
data.content: Describes pathogens that are generally free-living, but can cause disease if given the opportunity

data.title: Parasites
data.content: Organisms that obtain nutrients from other host organisms

data.title: Saprophytes
data.content: Organisms that decompose dead organic material to obtain nutrients

data.title: Sterile
data.content: To be free from bacteria or other living microorganisms
